content.description: This crack--more like a series of mantles than a crack climb--offers a very mellow lead for a first-timer.
content.protection: Good protection the whole way up.
content.location: The second crack as you move to the right, around the corner from Poplar Crack.

content.description:
Start on the obvious line next to the tree, continue up the line to the top. Plenty of great feet and hands well within reach.

Amazing beginner route, terrific for kids and inexperienced climbers alike.
content.protection:
TR protection: there's a stand of trees near the top of the climb. If you want to use the massive bomber one on the next level up, bring a long static rope.

Didn't trad it, but it looked like it had plenty of places for pro. Top may be a little run out (minorly), but it's easy slab. You can top out and walk off the top.
content.location:
The route is the absolute farthest to the right at the crag. The next thing over is the clifftop access trail.

Obv landmark: there's a tree at the base of the climb, offset to the right.

content.description: Just to the right of Poplar Tree Crack, there are two bolts. Follow these up and take some small/med gear to finish the line. First 20 feet are the hardest part.
Full sustained 5.10a climbing. 10a move on small crimpers to jug, rest, repeat from start to finish with a nice bulge to pull before the finish.
One of 3 obvious crack lines on the main wall. This one would be the right crack of two just next to the bolted line 12b that leads up over a bulge to a small tree.
A great beginner climb. Some really fun moves. The crux comes about halfway up, could lie back to complete.
content.protection: If toproping, must use natural anchors. The crack starts off about fist width and gets gradually smaller. Cams and nuts should do the trick.
content.location: Right side of the main wall. The crack behind the large tulip poplar tree.

content.description: Nice juggy holds mixed in with sharp crimps. Try not to shift left onto the crack system.
content.protection:
Not a whole lot of on-route gear placements without moving left to the crack.

Good trees up top for building a TR. Bring at least 50' of static line. There are some great mid-sized cam placements (.5, .75, 1) in a block above the main wall.
content.location: Between Right Face and Right Crack, on the main wall in front of the access trail.

content.description: A fun crack climb. There are some large flakes out to the right of the climb. Could do some fun stemming moves towards the top.
content.protection: Small to Med. sized gear for Trad. Will need to build an anchor at the top or top-out and walk off. If top roping, need long static line to use trees or could place a #11 nut in the rock behind the top of the route, and use it for one side of the anchor.
content.location: The crack just to the right of The Changeling on the main wall.

content.description: Another Holloway Mountain crack climb--quite a bit shorter than Poplar Crack.
content.protection: A couple of pieces and you are good. Anchor off a tree.
content.location: The first of two obvious cracks, around the corner and to the right of Poplar Crack.

content.description: The most difficult route at Holloway. The bolts are a little rusty, but are still usable. May want to take a small rack to supplement in a couple of sketchy spots.
content.protection: Bolts. Can place some small passive pro as well.
content.location: The far-right bolted route on the main wall. perpendicular to the rest of the routes.
